ECON 2120: Principles of Microeconomics

Understanding Individual Consumers, Firms, and Markets

ECON 2120: Principles of Microeconomics

Course Overview

This course introduces the economic principles governing individual consumers, firms, and markets. Youâ€™ll learn how supply and demand determine prices, how consumers make decisions, why firms behave the way they do, and how different market structures affect competition and pricing. These concepts form the foundation for understanding how economies allocate resources and create value.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Apply supply and demand analysis to real markets
  • Understand consumer preferences and utility maximization
  • Analyze firm behavior and profit maximization
  • Evaluate market structures and competitive strategies
  • Calculate elasticity and understand its economic implications
  • Apply microeconomic principles to current business and policy decisions

Course Information

Interactive Learning Tools

Supply & Demand Visualizer

Create your own supply and demand curves and watch how shifts in supply or demand affect equilibrium price and quantity. Ideal for understanding market behavior.

Open Interactive Tool â†’

Elasticity Calculator

Calculate price elasticity, income elasticity, and cross-price elasticity for different goods. Understand how consumers respond to price changes.

Open Interactive Tool â†’

Consumer Choice Simulator

Explore consumer preferences, utility maximization, and budget constraints. See how income and price changes affect consumer decisions.

Open Interactive Tool â†’

Market Equilibrium Explorer

Analyze different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly) and understand how firms set prices and quantities.

Open Interactive Tool â†’

Participate in class polls and learning surveys (no names collected, 100% anonymous). Your feedback helps shape the course.

How to Succeed in This Course

  1. Attend class regularly - Material moves quickly in a 75-minute format
  2. Complete readings before class - Be prepared to participate in discussions
  3. Master the graphs - Microeconomics relies heavily on visual analysis; practice drawing and interpreting graphs
  4. Use interactive tools - These simulations help you develop intuition about market behavior
  5. Work practice problems - Work through problems independently before reviewing solutions
  6. Engage in discussion - Learn from your classmatesâ€™ perspectives
  7. Visit office hours - Donâ€™t wait until midterms to ask for help
